title: The Cat in the Hat
summary: Mike Myers stars in the title role of Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat, a film adaptation of the beloved literary classic.  (Universal Pictures)
critic_reviews: So good it breaks your heart for not being better. It is kept from brilliance by a soggy climax and a clumsy central narrative device.
Myers' Cat, with a voice that crosses Bert Lahr's Cowardly Lion with Mel Blanc's Bugs Bunny, is generally fun, possessed of an anarchic playfulness that balances his sometimes bawdy tendencies.

It's moderately engaging for the first half-hour, somewhat trying during the second half hour, and virtually unbearable over the final twenty minutes. It's a marginally recommendable film for kids, but not necessarily for parents.
It's another overwrought clunker like "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," all effects and stunts and CGI and prosthetics, with no room for lightness and joy.
Long on visual dazzle but short on warmth, and the humor is excessively raunchy for a family film.

Attractively designed, energetically performed and, above all, blessedly concise, this adaptation of one of the most popular American kids' books of all time walks the safe side of surrealism with its fur-flying shenanigans. The younger the viewers, the better reactions are bound to be.
Myers is the movie's fatal flaw, squeezing out the other characters who fatten the plot, mostly with an eye to parents.
Emerges as a lackluster and nearly charmless affair.
Left me feeling empty inside. There’s no warmth and character from the original Dr. Seuss book, and there’s no substance or soul in the story elements.

A few laughs come from Alec Baldwin as Mom’s posturing, deceitful boyfriend, but attempts at inserting risqué modern humour sit uneasily with the playfully innocent surrealism of Seuss’ famous characters.
Although a literal movie adaptation of Seuss' 1957 classic "The Cat in the Hat" might have run 20 minutes, is it too much to ask that the filmed material preserve the author's sensibility?
A semi-intriguing abomination, the movie The Cat in the Hat takes a piece of classic childhood Americana and turns it into something garish, dumb, ugly and senseless.

Very young children, it should be said, probably won't have any problem with the movie. It's bright and perky on the surface. But for anyone mature enough to pay closer attention, it's going to fall short of expectations.

Grazer's writing team has filled up the film's 82 minutes with winking product placements, SNL-type goofs, PG gags premised on not quite cursing, a Smashmouth cover of the Beatles' "Getting Better," and a lame subplot about a scuzzy lothario (Stephen Baldwin).

Someone (Myers?) came up with the bright idea of turning the Cat in the Hat into the worst Vegas nightclub spritzer of 1958. He's become a furry version of Rip Taylor: a walking, talking vaudeville idiot box.
It's a sort of soullessly cheerful cynicism that is about as far from Seuss as one can imagine.
Talk about your quick-buck exploitation.
As a British politician said of a corrupt but articulate peer, "The Cat in the Hat" is like a rotten mackerel seen by moonlight: It shines as it stinks.
Charmless and grating and immediately forgettable.
It pains me to tell you, But really, it's true: The Cat in the Hat  Is a piece of dog doo.
Where "The Cat" book was anarchistic but ultimately sweet-spirited, this movie is ugly, dumb and colossally mean-spirited.
Everything to treasure about that magical, slightly malevolent feline of childhood verse is obliterated in the coarse, charmless Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat.
Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat is gorged with shtick and gadgetry. When it comes to highlighting everything better left in the dark, it makes even the Matrix sequels look like works of genius.
It is an embarrassment and an insult to a character that has been beloved by kids for 45 years.
A vulgar, uninspired lump of poisoned eye candy.
The movie is crass and vulgar almost beyond belief.
Frenetic and cheerless action aside, the film's real problem is the Cat, who looks most unmagically like a second-string college sports mascot and conducts himself like a risque baggy-pants comedian.
If the producers had dug up Ted Geisel's body and hung it from a tree, they couldn't have desecrated the man more.
I do hate to say it -- it's really a drag, but why did they let this Cat out of the bag?

They've taken a classic and they've battered it senseless and, boy, does it stink. It’s so bad it’s amazing it's being released, and box office-goers might soon end up fleeced. And annoyed and bewildered, perhaps even creeped-out by this cacophonous mess which is awful throughout.

Such a remarkable rift between its charming source material and its heinous cinematic realization that the producers may as well have skipped the hassle of securing licensing rights and simply called this mess Mike Myers: A--hole in Fur.

Critics are paid to suffer bad art,
no matter how icky it is from the start. So all we could do was to Sit! Sit! Sit! Sit!  And we did not like it.  Not one little bit.
Like being run over by a garbage truck that backs up and dumps its load on top of you. It's a sloppy and vulgar burlesque, one of the most repulsive kiddie movies ever made.

The ongoing cinematic desecration of Dr. Seuss' legacy continues with The Cat In The Hat, a clattering abomination that makes it depressingly likely that an entire generation of reading-averse children will know The Cat In The Hat as that obnoxious character Mike Myers played in that horrible movie.
Comes scarily close to being the most unendurable Hollywood creation of the last dozen years.
The narrative itself, attributed to three former "Seinfeld" writers who also worked on "The Grinch," reeks of desperation.

reviews.content: What happens when you give a guy with no directing experience the opportunity to direct a film based on a Dr. Seuss book? You get "The Cat in the Hat," one of the worst films of all time. Poorly-acted, poorly-written, completely inappropriateWhat happens when you give a guy with no directing experience the opportunity to direct a film based on a Dr. Seuss book? You get "The Cat in the Hat," one of the worst films of all time. Poorly-acted, poorly-written, completely inappropriate for it's intended audience, indescribably annoying, and filled with awful, annoying characters, "The Cat in the Hat" becomes unlikeable from the jump. As soon as I saw the Cat on the poster...well, I jumped because he looked kinda creepy, but I also knew that I was in for a bad time. If I can say ONE good thing about this abomination, it's that it's relatively short, but this definitely feels much longer than the 82 minutes it claims to be. This film is an absolute travesty, and no one deserves to put themselves through this. Please, don't watch this. I BEG of you, DO NOT watch this film UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES.
Awful, just plain awful. This is most disrespectful to Seuss's classic book. It's a good thing that Audrey Geisel decided to stop Universal making live-action Seuss movies.
The humour was average, the rest of the movie was boring. It's nothing like the book until the part where it starts raining. Only watch if you loved the book so much that you will enjoy this movie.

Where do I begin to describe this awful mess of a film? A film that has no right to be called a "family film", a film that does everything it can to not be funny, a film that wastes the talent of Mike Myers in the lead role as Dr. Seuss' "TheWhere do I begin to describe this awful mess of a film? A film that has no right to be called a "family film", a film that does everything it can to not be funny, a film that wastes the talent of Mike Myers in the lead role as Dr. Seuss' "The Cat in the Hat". The movie, directed by Bo Welch, sees two kids Conrad (Spencer Breslin) and Sally (Dakota Fanning) often misbehaving, and their single mother, Joan (Kelly Preston) who works in a Real Estate tries to get them to understand how to behave. Conrad ends up messing the house up, and it seems that Joan is dating their next door neighbor, Lawrence (Alec Baldwin), which Conrad isn't happy with. One day, the kids find out that there is a strange, human-like sized cat in their house, this turns out to be "The Cat in the Hat" (an obnoxious Mike Myers), who causes chaos once he has entered their lives. We see the Cat doing many crazy and obnoxious things, much to the point where you'd think the movie's plot has gone out for a walk. The colorful cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki, is more of an eye-sore than it is eye-popping. There is no sense of realism, but at the same time, there is also no sense of whimsy... it lives in a fantasy world where everything is animated to the point where you'd also think, why is this live action, again? The humor in this film is also ill-timed, take a scene for example, where Mike Myers' the Cat sees a picture of the children's mother and his hat expands in size as he lustfully gazes at this picture, then the kids tell him that's their mother. Adult humor is allowed in kids' films and can work, but only when its subtle, this joke was not subtle in the slightest. None of them are. Take another scene, where we see our main characters riding along some kind of fantasy roller-coaster, and then the movie stops just so Mike Myers, as the Cat, can insert a little plug to a Universal Studios ride. The product placement and obvious advertising is shameful and should not have been in there to begin with. This is a painful movie to sit through, none of the jokes are timed properly, none of the plot makes much sense, and the movie is just weird to look at. Family films could not get more obnoxious than this.

This was best what they could do? at this point i wasnt satisfied even in 2015 or any time period i rather watch a movie from 90's but not this jokes are terrible nothing really gives this movie anything at all

The logos > Everything else. I can't believe that such emotional logos had to come in a terrible adaption that's a disgrace to Dr. Seuss's good name. The next time I see this movie, I'd only be in it for the logos and then leave afterwards.The logos > Everything else. I can't believe that such emotional logos had to come in a terrible adaption that's a disgrace to Dr. Seuss's good name. It's like they threw away the charming from the book and use Mike Myers to destroy the movie to become such a mature movie for kids who loves the Cat in the Hat book. How did Mike Myers destroy this movie you say and what mature content am I talking about? Look at the many double entendres this movie is hiding and look at the potty humor this Cat's up to. Maybe Tim Allen could be a better Cat.
Mike Myers gives a hysterical, over the top performance of The Cat, however the rest of the movie is just a cluster of bad characters that are dull, boring, and uninteresting.

As a kid most books,I read were a bore.But Schulz's and Seuss'
I used to adore.

They were clever, delightful,
and ever so witty.

My favourite of Suess'
no doubt about that.
It was theAs a kid most books,I read were a bore.But Schulz's and Seuss'I used to adore.They were clever, delightful,and ever so witty.And Seuss' cool rhymes,made for a nice ditty.My favourite of Suess'no doubt about that.It was the timeless tale,of the Cat in the Hat.Then the movie came out,when I was just eight.I was so excited,I just couldn't wait.My parents let me see it,I was ever so glad.Little did I know,it would be so bad.The film ignored Seuss completely,and "modernised" the tale.Every new addition,was an utter fail.They pandered to kids,I noticed even back then.And the jokes were outdated,even in that Gen.I walked out disappointed,a frown on my face,I thought compared to the book,the movie was a disgrace.Do not rent or borrow,and definitely don't buy.I hope this review,has informed you why.
I'm not here to sing the praises of The Cat In The Hat. I'm not even going to defend it, but call me crazy, I laughed during this movie. I really laughed, at more than a few points in the film.
The movie has a terrible story and bad acting. The movie has some good jokes, but most are weird. The last bad part is the characters look bad, really bad. It was not good at all.
You know why this is bad. I didn't have to write a review, but I am. look, it could've been a good movie if..................................it wasn't so horrible.

It became popular to hate on this movie years ago and it's really unjustified. There's a few things contributing to the hate. First, it's aimed at older kids and the mum forced to watch with them, not the adults commenting. Second, Dr SeussIt became popular to hate on this movie years ago and it's really unjustified. There's a few things contributing to the hate. First, it's aimed at older kids and the mum forced to watch with them, not the adults commenting. Second, Dr Seuss is a popular author, but only in some places. In places like where I live, hardly anyone grows up reading Dr Seuss. This is nothing like its source material. It's sarcastic and third-wall breaking. Third, all it takes is some person on Youtube saying something is bad for my generation to pretend they have no ability to think for themselves. Movie critics on Youtube hate this movie. But for me, I liked this when it came out. It was funny and campy like watching the old series of Batman. Yes, the humour is the kind you roll your eyes at, but that's what it's meant to be. This isn't aiming for groundbreaking. It's aiming for a casual Saturday afternoon where your kids are watching Looney Tunes. It's not aiming for accuracy, it's aiming for parody. And it succeeds. Looney Tunes did the exact same **** But notice how nobody breathes a word of criticism? As for Mike Myers, I liked him in this role. I think people saying he's miscast is, I think, an example of how some people just don't get this brand of humour. He was fine for the kind of role this was.

Bo Welch never directed a film before in his life, and will never direct again because this film killed his directing career before it really started. If you're going to make a Dr. Seuss film, Hollywood, at least make the message clear andBo Welch never directed a film before in his life, and will never direct again because this film killed his directing career before it really started. If you're going to make a Dr. Seuss film, Hollywood, at least make the message clear and the visual style resemble the book. That's the LEAST you can do, AND GET A REAL DIRECTOR, NOT A PRODUCTION DESIGNER!!!! And second, DON'T EXTEND THE PLOT OF THE MOVIE. STICK TO THE CENTRE OF WHAT MADE THE ORIGINAL CAT IN THE HAT BOOK GREAT: GREAT DRAWINGS, GREAT MESSAGE THAT RULE BREAKING IS OKAY AS LONG AS IT NEVER GOES TOO FAR, MODERATE IT. KEEP THE MESSAGE FOCUSED AND CLEAR IF YOU'RE DEMANDING A LONGER MOVIE. DON'T WRITE PENIS INNUENDO JOKES INTO THE FILM. THAT'S NOT KIDS STUFF. If you want to see a GOOD Dr. Seuss film, see Horton Hears A Who.

I'm probably going to be cursed for giving this movie a good review, but honestly, I don't care. It's my opinion. My childhood was never full of Dr. Suess-related stuff. Sure I have fond memories of reading "Green Eggs and Ham" and "One FishI'm probably going to be cursed for giving this movie a good review, but honestly, I don't care. It's my opinion. My childhood was never full of Dr. Suess-related stuff. Sure I have fond memories of reading "Green Eggs and Ham" and "One Fish Two Fish Red Fish Blue Fish," but I didn't feel like my childhood was getting stabbed in the movie. Sure, some of the material in the movie shouldn't be shown to kids, but I'm an adult, so I'm fine. And honestly, in 2003, I was more offended by Ang Lee's  Hulk movie then this.

This film is extremely underrated and misunderstood, and I am going to explain the truth about it in this review. Though it is quite different to the book which it is based on, it is hard to make a very short book into a long film. Also, it is hard to make a non animated version of a Doctor Seuss film. I think this film has become popular to hate, many people I've seen talking about it haven't even explained why they don't like it, they're probably just following popular culture. Sure Doctor Seuss's wife made it clear after this film was made that she hated it, but she was probably fed up after all the Doctor Seuss film adaptations up to that point, this film was probably just the final straw before she banned live action adaptations of Doctor Seuss's book. The acting in this film is good, so is the set design. The villain in it gets his comeuppance, it is funny when the fish says "Oh my cod''. This film adds in interesting subplots, it isn't too long, it has a good soundtrack and it is fun to watch because of it's craziness.

Woah, woah, take it easy people! It wasn't THAT bad! Yes, there are subtle innuendoes. They'll go right over kid's heads! Ok, the one where the Cat mentions his car which has a name that's an acronym for s**t was a step too far but theWoah, woah, take it easy people! It wasn't THAT bad! Yes, there are subtle innuendoes. They'll go right over kid's heads! Ok, the one where the Cat mentions his car which has a name that's an acronym for s**t was a step too far but the others? Nothing that will prompt questions from your kids. Mike Myers was actually pretty good as the cat in my opinion. He was the best thing about the movie! I had a lot of laughs and my biggest complaints were the fact that there were a few SUPER gross scenes, and I found the mother's boss annoying. It's a decent film, unless you think that putting innuendoes in a Dr. Seuss movie is sacrilegious. It really doesn't deserve its 19 metascore.
I definitely loved this film! I knew I was watching a Dr. Seuss classic as soon as the film started. The jokes were hilarious and super witty- my kind of jokes :)
WHAT a bad representation to the best Dr. Seuss book of 1957, I can't believe I had this movie on VHS, I was confused as a kid watching this in 2006, what a disaster to the fans!

This film is utterly disgusting. I was actually thinking that, hey, the movie critics could be wrong about this movie, they were on Equilibrium. Then I heard actual people talking about how crappy this movie was. I was pretty convinced after This film is utterly disgusting. I was actually thinking that, hey, the movie critics could be wrong about this movie, they were on Equilibrium. Then I heard actual people talking about how crappy this movie was. I was pretty convinced after a week since it was out that it sucked, horribly. So what possessed me to see this film? Okay, I have this theatre in my town. 1.99 for one ticket. I was extremely bored one day so I decided to go to that theatre to see a movie. I had already seen everything they were playing except for the Cat in the Hat. I decide, hell why not, it might be good, besides, its only 2 dollars. I feel extremely ripped off, that's how bad this movie is. Okay, if you don't know the cat in the hat's plot I suggest you go get a life or maybe end it. The cat in the hat is a story everyone knows. The thing is is that they screwed up such a basic story that it leads me to wonder if they actually read the book. The jokes in this movie were just horrible. Okay, I did laugh a few times, kind of. The thing is is that the jokes were crude and unfitting of this movie. If you want a family film everyone can enjoy, try to put humor in their that is non offensve and funny at the same time, I can think of a few ways you could do that. Mike Meyers plays a horrible cat. He kept on sonding like Doctor Evil or Austin Powers. Maybne that is just how I interpret him. The classic Dr. Suess rhyming was kept at such a minimum that it lead me to beleive who ever wrote the script is in need of an imagination. This movie should have aimed for young children, instead, they decided they should aim it at every age group and then fail horribly. The Cat in the Hat is one of the worst book to movie adaption ever, and also one of the worst movioes of the year (beat only by Gigli, From Justin to Kelly, and Malibus Most Wanted).

I watched a lot of this on telivison, hopefully to find something to laugh at...and the whole time I keep pressing the Info button on the remote to see if it really is PG. These jokes don't even fly over the kids' heads. They're in your face kind of humor. And the story! Two kids are trying to stop their mom from marrying the world's biggest jerk, who wants to punish the boy and send him off to military school and some crap like that... It's terrfying.

The combination of an arguably classic children's book with risque adult humor, anarchistic Shrek-esque children's humor, gratuitous cheesy content, and screaming in your ear for the next 45 minutes results in a uniquely abominable The combination of an arguably classic children's book with risque adult humor, anarchistic Shrek-esque children's humor, gratuitous cheesy content, and screaming in your ear for the next 45 minutes results in a uniquely abominable extravaganza that just doesn't seem to work (and really shouldn't in the first place.) Please spare yourself and your children. Don't see this movie.

I recognise a masterpiece when I see one and the cat in the hat is one of the most perfect comedies I've ever seen and you should absolutely watch it.The story was fantastic, I hated the original dr Seuss book because it had good morals andI recognise a masterpiece when I see one and the cat in the hat is one of the most perfect comedies I've ever seen and you should absolutely watch it.The story was fantastic, I hated the original dr Seuss book because it had good morals and it was well written, thankfully this movie has none of these elements. They found a way to make the story boring, pandering and annoying which is so refreshing, the visual style is amazing creating a very ugly and fake looking world which blew me away.The characters were great as well, they were so unfunny and annoying that I couldn't wait for the movie to be over, the cat character was poorly written and poorly acted, you could just tell he couldn't wait for his paycheck which made the film so charming and likable.This is one of the best movies of all time, it completely misunderstood the meaning of the original material, the story and characters were so incredibly annoying that they made this movie a masterpiece, to all critics who didn't like this movie you just need to have a better brain and laugh at these smart jokes because the movie really made me LOL.

While Mike Myers, though he did help make the jokes funny, wasn't the perfect casting, honestly, and the Things are horrendous, but I likeListen; this movie is a mixed bag for me. It's both stupid yet amazing. It's annoying yet hilarious. While Mike Myers, though he did help make the jokes funny, wasn't the perfect casting, honestly, and the Things are horrendous, but I like the actors for Sally and "Conrad" (Nick). Despite my mixed feelings about this film, I don't hate it, but I don't necessarily "like" it, either, though it's going more towards me liking it then hating it.

I was once a homeless man wandering the streets of England but after watching this movie my life changed. This movie taught me the importance of learning and helped me overcome my anxiety in the work place. The cats whiskers made me so jolly.I was once a homeless man wandering the streets of England but after watching this movie my life changed. This movie taught me the importance of learning and helped me overcome my anxiety in the work place. The cats whiskers made me so jolly. I even occasionally dress up as my hero, "the cat in the hat" for important business meetings giving me the confidence I need to shine like the star I have always been. I hope one day I can become as amazing as my hero. Today I am not only a fully grown man, but a national treasure to my community and nation. My journey all started with this movie. Watch this movie and be prepared for your life to change for the better.Please rate this movie 10 stars if you had similar experiences or are excited of the invaluable prospects this movie has to offer.

This was such a funny movie and is way overhated! It would be impossible to make a movie of that book without adding a lot to it, and they did pretty well with that. Mike Myers was perfect as the cat and he was a big part of what made theThis was such a funny movie and is way overhated! It would be impossible to make a movie of that book without adding a lot to it, and they did pretty well with that. Mike Myers was perfect as the cat and he was a big part of what made the film so entertaining. I liked the new characters they added such as Alec Baldwin as the antagonist and Mrs Kwan. The kids and the mom of course have more personality than they did in the book. The designs of everything are cool and look very Dr Seuss like. I watched this movie as a kid and loved it, and I watched it again when I was older and it’s even better since I get more of the adult jokes. The Austin Powers type of humour is what made this one of if not the funniest kids movie of all time! The book was a classic and very charming, and the movie is super fun to watch. This movie does not deserve the amount of hate it gets and if you think of it more as a parody than a film adaption, there is no reason to not like it!
